paper_abstract: This study is the third in a series of design-based research on a technology-enhanced cognitive apprenticeship (TECA) that uses a variety of technology (e.g. video, discussion boards, performance support) to support triad member activity during the clinical experience. The purpose of this study was to examine the differences in communication and performance among student teachers, who participated in the TECA during a year-long clinical experience and those who did not. Overall, performance scores were higher among students in the TECA; planning scores were higher at a statistically significant level. Communication reports suggest that online discussions through both public and private channels contributed to these results. Findings were consistent with prior studies of the TECA and supported the efficacy of key design elements. Implications for teacher education and the design of TECAs are discussed. (C) 2013 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
paper_title: Student teacher communication and performance during a clinical experience supported by a technology-enhanced cognitive apprenticeship
